channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Can India's new billion-dollar funding agency boost research?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02336-8

India’s proposed National Research Foundation will shake up the scientific landscape to encourage a culture of research.
item.dc:title: Can India's new billion-dollar funding agency boost research?
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Rings of fire: centuries of tree growth show wildfires increasing in Vietnam
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02235-y

The data suggest human activities are more to blame for the increase than climate change.
item.dc:title: Rings of fire: centuries of tree growth show wildfires increasing in Vietnam
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: Quantum sensors: detect heart disease sooner
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02247-8

Quantum sensors: detect heart disease sooner
item.dc:title: Quantum sensors: detect heart disease sooner

item.dc:creator: Krystyna M. Saunders
Karina T. Meredith

item.title: How a simple celebratory gathering can offer a positive outlook
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02350-w

My research area in the biological sciences department has a simple end-of-semester ceremony that helps us to share our successes, writes Ilinca Ciubotariu.
item.dc:title: How a simple celebratory gathering can offer a positive outlook
item.dc:creator: Ilinca Ciubotariu

item.title: From the archive: computer security, and a key experiment by Pascal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02294-1

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: computer security, and a key experiment by Pascal

item.title: How to educate the world: prioritize funding and data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02327-9

Data gaps are hindering progress on the Sustainable Development Goal for education and lifelong learning. Modest funding will help to fill them.
item.dc:title: How to educate the world: prioritize funding and data

item.title: The true cost of science’s language barrier for non-native English speakers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02320-2

Survey quantifies the extra time that researchers whose first language isn't English need to read, write and present data.
item.dc:title: The true cost of science’s language barrier for non-native English speakers
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Water pollution 'timebomb' threatens global health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02337-7

Simulations predict a water-pollution crisis by the end of the century.
item.dc:title: Water pollution 'timebomb' threatens global health
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: EU proposal on CRISPR-edited crops is welcome — but not enough
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02328-8

The door should be opened further: CRISPR has huge potential to boost food security in the face of pathogens and climate change.
item.dc:title: EU proposal on CRISPR-edited crops is welcome — but not enough
item.dc:creator: Devang Mehta

item.title: Medicine is plagued by untrustworthy clinical trials. How many studies are faked or flawed?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02299-w

Investigations suggest that, in some fields, at least one-quarter of clinical trials might be problematic or even entirely made up, warn some researchers. They urge stronger scrutiny.
item.dc:title: Medicine is plagued by untrustworthy clinical trials. How many studies are faked or flawed?
item.dc:creator: Richard Van Noorden

item.title: My glacier is melting — and I’m charting its decline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02308-y

Glaciologist Andrea Fischer describes her first-hand experience of studying these ever-changing ice masses.
item.dc:title: My glacier is melting — and I’m charting its decline
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: To save bears, we must learn to live alongside them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02301-5

With urban areas expanding and climate change shrinking bears’ habitats, the animals’ interactions with humans will make — or break — efforts to preserve their populations.
item.dc:title: To save bears, we must learn to live alongside them
item.dc:creator: Henry Nicholls

item.title: Do you take part in genetic studies? That might be in your genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02309-x

Findings could help researchers to better understand ‘participation bias’ in studies that link genomics with health, behaviour and other traits.
item.dc:title: Do you take part in genetic studies? That might be in your genes
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Sleeping embryonic genomes are awoken by OBOX proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01618-5

Activation of gene transcription is precisely regulated in early embryos. The identification of key transcription factors now shows how the transcription machinery is guided to the right place at the right time in mice.
item.dc:title: Sleeping embryonic genomes are awoken by OBOX proteins
item.dc:creator: Edlyn Wu
Nadine L. Vastenhouw

item.title: Alzheimer’s drug donanemab helps most when taken at earliest disease stage, study finds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02321-1

But the drug, an antibody that attacks the protein amyloid, does not work as well in people with more advanced disease.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s drug donanemab helps most when taken at earliest disease stage, study finds
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How better sleep can improve productivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02307-z

Struggling to get a good night’s rest after a long day in the lab? Sleep specialists offer some advice.
item.dc:title: How better sleep can improve productivity
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: How to introduce quantum computers without slowing economic growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02317-x

To smooth the path of the quantum revolution, researchers and governments must predict and prepare for the traps ahead.
item.dc:title: How to introduce quantum computers without slowing economic growth
item.dc:creator: Chander Velu
Fathiro H. R. Putra

item.title: How much snow is on Mount Everest? Scientists climbed it to find out
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02257-6

Researchers who summited the world’s tallest peak found much more snow there than expected.
item.dc:title: How much snow is on Mount Everest? Scientists climbed it to find out

item.title: India's Moon lander successfully launches — but biggest challenge lies ahead
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02329-7

Chandrayaan 3 will attempt to join the exclusive club of countries that have explored the lunar surface.
item.dc:title: India's Moon lander successfully launches — but biggest challenge lies ahead
item.dc:creator: T. V. Padma

item.title: Deep-sea mining could soon be approved — how bad is it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02290-5

The creatures at the bottom of the ocean are little-studied, but emerging data hint at long-term damage from efforts to harvest metals on the sea floor.
item.dc:title: Deep-sea mining could soon be approved — how bad is it?
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Aspartame is a possible carcinogen: the science behind the decision
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02306-0

More research is needed to investigate a potential link between the common sweetener and cancer.
item.dc:title: Aspartame is a possible carcinogen: the science behind the decision
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Daily briefing: Birds build nests from anti-bird spikes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02339-5

Crows and magpies are building nests with the metal spikes meant to deter them. Plus, 14 things you need to know if you are thinking about collaborating with data scientists.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Birds build nests from anti-bird spikes
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Daily briefing: When your laboratory burns to the ground
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02324-y

How one research group recovered from an all-consuming fire. Plus, giant-sloth jewellery could change our understanding of human history and the oceans are turning greener owing to climate change.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: When your laboratory burns to the ground
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Fourteen things you need to know about collaborating with data scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02291-4

Experimentalists often need help to analyse data. Here’s how to ensure your collaboration is productive.
item.dc:title: Fourteen things you need to know about collaborating with data scientists
item.dc:creator: Michele Tobias
Nick Ulle
Tyler Shoemaker

item.title: ChatGPT gives an extra productivity boost to weaker writers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02270-9

The AI program allows people with limited writing skills to create higher-quality texts — but makes little difference to proficient writers’ work quality.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT gives an extra productivity boost to weaker writers
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Rapid COVID tests miss 90% of asymptomatic cases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02254-9

But if the tests work much better when taken three times over the course of several days.
item.dc:title: Rapid COVID tests miss 90% of asymptomatic cases

item.title: ChatGPT can write a paper in an hour — but there are downsides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02298-x

A roundup of stories from the Nature Briefing, including the pros and cons of writing a paper with AI, record-breaking global temperatures, and a protein that boosts monkeys’ memories.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT can write a paper in an hour — but there are downsides
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker
Benjamin Thompson
Dan Fox

item.title: Supersonic ‘bullets’ are softly captured by a protein gel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02253-w

Stone projectiles are brought to a halt by a 5-millimetres-thick film rich in a protein that cushions cells from pressure.
item.dc:title: Supersonic ‘bullets’ are softly captured by a protein gel

item.title: Stunning star nursery is latest JWST image to amaze astronomers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02289-y

Powerful space telescope reveals star-forming region — image of the week.
item.dc:title: Stunning star nursery is latest JWST image to amaze astronomers

item.title: Co-transplantation of autologous T<sub>reg</sub> cells in a cell therapy for Parkinson’s disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06300-4

In mouse and rat models of Parkinson’s disease, co-transplanting regulatory T cells (Treg cells) improves the survival of grafted midbrain dopamine neurons in cell therapies by reducing the inflammatory response caused by surgical injury.
item.dc:title: Co-transplantation of autologous T<sub>reg</sub> cells in a cell therapy for Parkinson’s disease

item.title: Assembly of functional diversity in an oceanic island flora
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06305-z

On the oceanic island of Tenerife, dispersal, speciation and persistence drive the diversity and distribution of plant functional traits.
item.dc:title: Assembly of functional diversity in an oceanic island flora

item.title: Practical recommendations for using ctDNA in clinical decision making
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06225-y

This Perspective reviews the utility and interpretation of circulating tumour DNA for the detection of residual and recurrent cancers and provides recommendations regarding its clinical application for a variety of solid tumours.
item.dc:title: Practical recommendations for using ctDNA in clinical decision making
item.dc:creator: Stacey A. Cohen
Minetta C. Liu
Alexey Aleshin

item.title: Large language models encode clinical knowledge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06291-2

Med-PaLM, a state-of-the-art large language model for medicine, is introduced and evaluated across several medical question answering tasks, demonstrating the promise of these models in this domain.
item.dc:title: Large language models encode clinical knowledge

item.title: Agricultural pesticide land budget and river discharge to oceans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06296-x

A global assessment of the mobility of 92 agricultural pesticides from points of application in major agricultural catchments downstream to rivers and oceans identifies flow pathways and pollution hotspots in which monitoring could improve risk mitigation.
item.dc:title: Agricultural pesticide land budget and river discharge to oceans
item.dc:creator: Federico Maggi
Fiona H. M. Tang
Francesco N. Tubiello

item.title: Mast cells link immune sensing to antigen-avoidance behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06188-0

Mast cells are shown to function as sensor cells linking antigen recognition in type 2 immunity to antigen-specific avoidance behaviour, preventing immune activation and inflammation.
item.dc:title: Mast cells link immune sensing to antigen-avoidance behaviour

item.title: Homomeric chains of intermolecular bonds scaffold octahedral germanium perovskites
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06209-y

We report assembly of an organic scaffold within perovskite structures, resulting in the suppression of the lone pair expression of Ge and templating the symmetric octahedra.
item.dc:title: Homomeric chains of intermolecular bonds scaffold octahedral germanium perovskites

item.title: Linear-in-temperature resistivity for optimally superconducting (Nd,Sr)NiO<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06129-x

By moving to a substrate that better stabilizes conditions, the doping series of Nd1–xSrxNiO2 is synthesized free from extended defects, resulting in enhancement of superconductivity in terms of transition temperature and range of doping.
item.dc:title: Linear-in-temperature resistivity for optimally superconducting (Nd,Sr)NiO<sub>2</sub>

item.title: Generation of genuine entanglement up to 51 superconducting qubits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06195-1

A scalable approach is provided for preparing and verifying intermediate-scale genuine entanglement on a 66-qubit superconducting quantum processor.
item.dc:title: Generation of genuine entanglement up to 51 superconducting qubits

item.title: PLSCR1 is a cell-autonomous defence factor against SARS-CoV-2 infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06322-y

Phospholipid scramblase 1 (PLSCR1), a protein induced by IFNγ, acts as a defence factor against SARS-CoV-2 and other coronaviruses by inhibiting the fusion of the virus with host-cell membranes.
item.dc:title: PLSCR1 is a cell-autonomous defence factor against SARS-CoV-2 infection

item.title: Retrotransposons hijack alt-EJ for DNA replication and eccDNA biogenesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06327-7

Retrotransposons hijack the alternative end-joining DNA repair process of the host for a circularization step to synthesize their second-strand DNA.
item.dc:title: Retrotransposons hijack alt-EJ for DNA replication and eccDNA biogenesis
item.dc:creator: Fu Yang
Weijia Su

item.title: Diverse organic-mineral associations in Jezero crater, Mars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06143-z

Raman and fluorescence spectra, consistent with several species of aromatic organic molecules, are reported in the Crater Floor sequences of Jezero crater, Mars, suggesting multiple mechanisms of organic synthesis, transport, or preservation.
item.dc:title: Diverse organic-mineral associations in Jezero crater, Mars

item.title: Fluidic self-assembly for MicroLED displays by controlled viscosity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06167-5

A MicroLED lighting panel, assembled in 60 s by a surface-tension-driven fluidic self-assembly technique, gave a yield as high as 99.90% through the addition of a small amount of poloxamer to the assembly solution.
item.dc:title: Fluidic self-assembly for MicroLED displays by controlled viscosity

item.title: A planetary health innovation for disease, food and water challenges in Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06313-z

By harvesting aquatic vegetation that provides habitat for snails that harbour Schistosoma parasites and converting it to compost and animal feed, a trial reduced schistosomiasis prevalence in children while providing wider economic benefits.
item.dc:title: A planetary health innovation for disease, food and water challenges in Africa
item.dc:creator: Jason R. Rohr
Alexandra Sack
Sidy Bakhoum
Christopher B. Barrett
David Lopez-Carr
Andrew J. Chamberlin

Caitlin Wolfe

item.title: Spatially resolved multiomics of human cardiac niches
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06311-1

Single-cell and spatial transcriptomic analysis of eight human heart tissues reveals the cellular profiles and tissue architecture of niches including the cardiac conduction system, and a new tool, drug2cell, identifies drug target expression.
item.dc:title: Spatially resolved multiomics of human cardiac niches
item.dc:creator: Kazumasa Kanemaru
James Cranley
Daniele Muraro
Antonio M. A. Miranda
Siew Yen Ho

Sarah A. Teichmann

item.title: Plastic pollution on the world’s coral reefs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06113-5

Plastics were found in 77 out of 84 coral reefs surveyed in the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans, including in deeper reefs and remote and near-pristine reefs, such as in uninhabited central Pacific atolls.
item.dc:title: Plastic pollution on the world’s coral reefs
item.dc:creator: Hudson T. Pinheiro
Chancey MacDonald
Robson G. Santos
Ramadhoine Ali
Ayesha Bobat
Benjamin J. Cresswell

Luiz A. Rocha

item.title: Single-electron spin resonance detection by microwave photon counting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06097-2

Spectroscopic measurements of individual rare-earth ion electron spins are performed by detecting their microwave fluorescence, with the method coming close to practical single-electron spin resonance at millikelvin temperatures.
item.dc:title: Single-electron spin resonance detection by microwave photon counting
item.dc:creator: Z. Wang
L. Balembois
M. Rančić
E. Billaud
M. Le Dantec
A. Ferrier
P. Goldner
S. Bertaina
T. Chanelière
D. Esteve
D. Vion
P. Bertet
E. Flurin

item.title: Complementary Alu sequences mediate enhancer–promoter selectivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06323-x

Using RNA in situ conformation sequencing technology, the role of Alu elements in mediating the interaction between enhancers and promoters is shown.
item.dc:title: Complementary Alu sequences mediate enhancer–promoter selectivity
item.dc:creator: Liang Liang
Changchang Cao
Lei Ji
Zhaokui Cai
Di Wang
Rong Ye
Juan Chen
Xiaohua Yu
Jie Zhou
Zhibo Bai
Ruoyan Wang
Xianguang Yang
Ping Zhu
Yuanchao Xue

item.title: Plastic debris in lakes and reservoirs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06168-4

Analysis of plastic debris found in surface waters shows that lakes and reservoirs in densely populated and urbanized regions, as well as those with elevated deposition areas, are particularly vulnerable to plastic contamination.
item.dc:title: Plastic debris in lakes and reservoirs
item.dc:creator: Veronica Nava

item.title: Quantum-enhanced Markov chain Monte Carlo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06095-4

A quantum algorithm is introduced that performs Markov chain Monte Carlo to sample from the Boltzmann distribution of Ising models, demonstrating, through experiments and simulations, a polynomial speedup compared with classical alternatives.
item.dc:title: Quantum-enhanced Markov chain Monte Carlo
item.dc:creator: David Layden
Guglielmo Mazzola
Ryan V. Mishmash
Mario Motta
Pawel Wocjan
Jin-Sung Kim
Sarah Sheldon

item.title: A framework for individualized splice-switching oligonucleotide therapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06277-0

Whole-genome sequencing analyses in a cohort of individuals with ataxia-telangiectasia are used to identify genetic variants that might be amenable to treatment with splice-switching antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs), and develop ASOs with therapeutic potential.
item.dc:title: A framework for individualized splice-switching oligonucleotide therapy
item.dc:creator: Jinkuk Kim
Sijae Woo
Claudio M. de Gusmao
Boxun Zhao
Diana H. Chin
Renata L. DiDonato

Timothy W. Yu

item.title: Global climate-change trends detected in indicators of ocean ecology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06321-z

An analysis of satellite data from July 2002–June 2022 shows that ocean colour, or remote-sensing reflectance, changed significantly during this period, and that this trend is likely to be driven by climate change.
item.dc:title: Global climate-change trends detected in indicators of ocean ecology
item.dc:creator: B. B. Cael
Kelsey Bisson
Emmanuel Boss
Stephanie Dutkiewicz
Stephanie Henson

item.title: High-throughput Oligopaint screen identifies druggable 3D genome regulators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06340-w

High-throughput DNA or RNA labelling with optimized Oligopaints (HiDRO) reveals more than 300 factors that influence genome folding during interphase, including 43 genes that were validated as either increasing or decreasing interactions between topologically associating domains.
item.dc:title: High-throughput Oligopaint screen identifies druggable 3D genome regulators
item.dc:creator: Daniel S. Park
Son C. Nguyen
Randi Isenhart
Parisha P. Shah
Wonho Kim
R. Jordan Barnett
Aditi Chandra
Jennifer M. Luppino

Eric F. Joyce

item.title: US congressional hearing produces heat but no light on COVID-origins debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02261-w

A showdown over an influential early publication has done little to prepare the country for the next pandemic, observers say.
item.dc:title: US congressional hearing produces heat but no light on COVID-origins debate
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Science’s gender gap: the shocking data that reveal its true extent
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02139-x

Analysis of which researchers publish, get credit, move around, get funding, collaborate and receive citations shows how deeply ingrained the bias against women is.
item.dc:title: Science’s gender gap: the shocking data that reveal its true extent
item.dc:creator: Virginia Valian

item.title: An in situ search for organic molecules in Mars’s Jezero Crater
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02007-8

Samples from the surface of Jezero Crater on Mars have been analysed by the SHERLOC instrument aboard NASA’s Perseverance rover. Signatures from these samples are consistent with the presence of organic molecules and, together with earlier measurements, could constitute the first in situ detection of organic molecules on another planet.
item.dc:title: An in situ search for organic molecules in Mars’s Jezero Crater

item.title: Plastic waste is everywhere — and countries must be held accountable for reducing it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02252-x

As UN negotiations on eliminating plastic pollution enter a crucial phase, researchers must play their part in designing adequate measurement, monitoring and compliance systems.
item.dc:title: Plastic waste is everywhere — and countries must be held accountable for reducing it

item.title: Regulatory T cells aid stem-cell therapy for Parkinson’s disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02177-5

Inflammation caused by surgical trauma limits the survival of transplanted stem-cell-derived neurons in rodent models of Parkinson’s disease. Co-transplanting immune cells called regulatory T cells improves the therapy’s efficacy.
item.dc:title: Regulatory T cells aid stem-cell therapy for Parkinson’s disease
item.dc:creator: Qizhi Tang

item.title: Striking images show plastic litter in the world’s most remote coral reefs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02271-8

Fishing nets, packaging and other debris threaten wildlife in some of the ocean’s deepest reef ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Striking images show plastic litter in the world’s most remote coral reefs
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Large-scale collaborations uncover global extent of plastic pollution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02175-7

Ambitious campaigns to sample plastic pollution in coral-reef and freshwater ecosystems demonstrate the value of international cooperation in assessing contamination to identify drivers and inform management.
item.dc:title: Large-scale collaborations uncover global extent of plastic pollution
item.dc:creator: Kara Lavender Law
Chelsea M. Rochman

item.title: Oceans are turning greener due to climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02262-9

Researchers are investigating exactly why this is happening and what it might signify.
item.dc:title: Oceans are turning greener due to climate change
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: The CDC is in crisis — can its new leader save it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02305-1

The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s new leader will inherit a number of challenges, including restoring public and political support for the agency. Plus, analysis uncovers a gene linked to long COVID and sediment from a small Canadian lake could become the official marker for the Anthropocene.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The CDC is in crisis — can its new leader save it?
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: A picture of plant functional diversity on an oceanic island
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01998-8

Extensive fieldwork reveals that island plants have similar functions to plants in other regions of the world, but that the island environment, along with biogeographical and evolutionary processes, filters the life-history characteristics and strategies of the plants, rendering the island flora functionally and ecologically distinct from others.
item.dc:title: A picture of plant functional diversity on an oceanic island

item.title: Germs, genes and soil: tales of pathogens past
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02154-y

Armed with DNA sequencers and powerful computational tools, archaeogeneticists are turning their attention towards ancient microbes to give bacteria their due in human history.
item.dc:title: Germs, genes and soil: tales of pathogens past
item.dc:creator: Amber Dance

item.title: A sustainable way to control the parasitic disease schistosomiasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02178-4

A trial in Senegal has tested an innovative method for tackling a common human parasitic disease. The approach reduced infection numbers and also offered agricultural and economic benefits.
item.dc:title: A sustainable way to control the parasitic disease schistosomiasis
item.dc:creator: Nathan C. Lo
Benjamin Arnold

item.title: A singular heart
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02140-4

Visions of a life.
item.dc:title: A singular heart
item.dc:creator: Preston Grassmann

item.title: A fast quantum route to random numbers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02176-6

Using a quantum computer to speed up one step in a textbook approach to generating random numbers proves to be a savvy strategy, and one that could make good use of quantum computers that will be available in the near future.
item.dc:title: A fast quantum route to random numbers
item.dc:creator: Mohan Sarovar
